subject: RE: [junit] Formatting results on a per suite basis

Have you taken a look at the 'junitreport' task?  It can take the file
set you pass in and generate report.
 
So basically, you can use xml report to generate xml file on each test
case class, then use the junitreport to group the ones you want
to go together for the report.  We are doing that so that we can
generate report based on each personl's reponsible packages.  Then we
can also use a file set that includes all the xml files as the overall
test report.  Here is a brief sample:
 
  <target name="personalReport">
    <junitreport>
      <fileset refid="test.id"/>
      <report format="frames" todir="${reports.tests}/${user}"/>
    </junitreport>
  </target>

  <target name="shaneReport" description="Shane's test reports">
    <fileset id="id" dir="${reports.tests}">
      <include name="TEST-package1.package2.TestCaseClass.xml"/>
      <include name="TEST-package1.package3.*.xml"/>
      <include name="TEST-package2.package4.xml"/>
    </fileset>
    <antcall target="personalReport">
      <param name="user" value="shane"/>
      <reference refid="id" torefid="test.id"/>
    </antcall>
  </target>
 
Hope this is helps.
 
Shane


	-----Original Message-----
	From: mtardifsitepak [mailto:mtardif@...] 
	Sent: Thursday, November 13, 2003 10:38 AM
	To: junit@yahoogroups.com
	Subject: [junit] Formatting results on a per suite basis
	
	
	I am calling JUnit from a task within ant (xml provided below).
When I
	run ant for my entire suite of tests, I get output which looks
like this:
	
	    [junit] Testcase: testRun took 1.979 sec
	    [junit] Testcase: testRun took 0.572 sec
	    [junit] Testcase: testRun took 0.451 sec
	    ...
	
	The problem here is that I have different suites containing
tests with
	the same name. My setup is an extensive hierarchy of tests where
each
	subdirectory contains an AllTests class calling addTestSuite for
each
	of the tests within the same directory and addTest for each
AllTests
	class in the first level of subdirectories. For example:
	
	    suite.addTest(test.com.sitepak.subdir.AllTests.suite());
	    suite.addTestSuite(test.com.sitepak.SSHTest.class);
	
	I have tried many approaches to solve this problem but none have
been
	satisfactory:
	
	1. I tried overriding the PlainJUnitResultFormatter class,
giving my
	own implementation of the methods defined in the
JUnitResultFormatter
	interface. Problem is, startTestSuite is only called once when
running
	all the AllTests test in the root directory. The reason is
probably
	that when I call addTest and then addTestSuite, the tests are
all
	being cumulated in what is considered the same suite.
	
	2. I then tried overridig the XMLJUnitResultFormatter, as stated
in
	some of the posting in this newsgroup. Once filtered through an
XSLT
	file, I'm sure I could get the name of the test and its
corresponding
	class in the same line in a nicely formatted HTML file. However,
I
	need immediate feedback when calling ant from the command line.
	
	3. I finally tried calling each test individually, as suggested
in the
	JUnit or Ant FAQ. This consists of providing the following XML
in ant:
	
	  <batchtest fork="yes">
	    <fileset dir="${src.tests}">
	      <include name="**/*Test*.java"/>
	      <exclude name="**/AllTests.java"/>
	    </fileset>
	  </batchtest>
	
	The problem with this approach is that tests are run
individually
	which makes it impossible to print a summary of the number of
tests
	which have failed during the run.
	
	If anyone has other suggestions, please let me know. Here is
context
	information which might be useful:
	
	Ant target:
	
	  <target name="run_tests" depends="init">
	    <property name="testcase"
value="test.com.sitepak.AllTests"/>
	    <junit printSummary="yes" fork="on">
	      <classpath refid="classpath.run"/>
	      <jvmarg value="-Xmx128m"/>
	      <formatter type="plain" usefile="false"/>
	      <test name="${testcase}"/>
	    </junit>
	  </target>
	
	Versions:
	
	  JUnit 3.8.1
	  Ant 1.6
	  Linux 2.4.21
